Sentence: Helena, the orphan daughter of a famous physician, is the ward of the Countess of Rousillon, and hopelessly in love with her (Countess) son, Count Bertram, who has been sent to the court of the King of France
Despite her (Countess) beauty and worth, Helena has no hope of attracting Bertram, since she (Helena) is of low birth and he (Bertram) is a nobleman
In return, she (Helena) is given the hand of any man in the realm; she (Helena) chooses Bertram

Helena is sent home to the Countess, and receives a letter from Bertram informing her (Helena) that he (Bertram) will never be her (Helena) true spouse unless she (Helena) can get his (Bertram) family ring from his (Bertram) finger, and become pregnant with his (Bertram) child--neither of which, he (Bertram) declares, will ever come to pass

With the connivance of the daughter, named Diana, she (Diana) contrives to trick Bertram: he (Bertram) gives Diana his (Bertram) ring as a token of his (Bertram) love, and when he (Bertram) comes to her (Diana) room at night, Helena is in the bed, and they make love without him (Bertram) realizing that it is her (Helena)
Meanwhile, false messengers have come to the camp bearing word that Helena is dead, and with the war drawing to a close, Bertram decides to return to France
Unknown to him (Bertram), Helena follows, accompanied by Diana and the Widow
However, he (Bertram) notices a ring on Bertram's finger that formerly belonged to Helena--it was a gift from the King after she (Helena) saved his (King) life
Chastened, Bertram consents to be a good husband to her (Helena), and there is general rejoicing
